Award.AwardTitle: Broadening Opportunities for Biologists by Bridging the Gap for Transfer Students

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Oklahoma State University has received an NSF Scholarships for Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) award for their project entitled The Broadening Opportunities for Biologists by Bridging the Gap for Transfer Students. This project will improve recruitment, retention, and graduation rates for students transferring from 2-year schools and pursuing bachelor's degrees in the life sciences at OSU and will provide 58 two-year scholarships to 29 academically talented and financially disadvantaged students. Program activities will increase interactions within and across cohorts and strengthen the support network and sense of community for S-STEM scholars.

S-STEM scholars will receive financial, academic, and professional development support. Academic support will include a peer-led orientation workshop; a 1-credit seminar class focused on career awareness, communication skills, and peer interactions; advising; peer mentoring; and tutoring (including supplemental instruction for courses identified as challenging for S-STEM scholars). Regular checkpoints encourage student participation in academic support services. A diversity of professional development activities will allow scholars to adapt program experiences to their interests, needs, and schedules. Professional development activities will focus on career awareness, job search strategies, and balancing professional and family life, as well as optional internships, research projects, professional society meetings, graduate school related activities, and outreach opportunities. Visits to previous (graduated) S-STEM scholars in graduate school and at job sites will provide direct connections to future careers. Other support services will include group-building activities before the start of the academic year so incoming students can build connections with current S-STEM scholars, as well as informal, family friendly activities. Project evaluation will focus on formative and summative assessment with qualitative and quantitative data collected from multiple sources to assess recruitment, retention, and graduation rates, as well as student experiences in and perceptions about the S-STEM program. Overall, the project will provide information on the resources needed by students to overcome barriers faced in the transfer from a two-year institution to a four-year school and on the support that will enable them to complete a B.S. and be prepared for the STEM workforce or graduate school.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The S-STEM program at Oklahoma State University (OSU) provided scholarships of up to $10,000 per year to students transferring from two-year colleges and pursuing bachelor’s degrees in biology, physiology, or zoology at OSU. Transfer students represent a growing population at OSU and other four-year institutions, with nearly half of science and engineering students in the US beginning college careers at two-year schools. However, transfer students can face challenges that reduce the likelihood that they will complete their STEM degree. We developed connections with two-year colleges in Oklahoma and surrounding states to recruit academically talented students to our program. We provided scholarships to 11 students, 10 of whom graduated from OSU with a STEM degree in the life sciences. In addition to financial support, we also provided S-STEM scholars with academic and professional development support. S-STEM scholars completed a 1-credit transfer orientation seminar during their first semester in the program. The seminar introduced students to OSU (campus resources, rules and regulations, etc.) and focused topics such as career awareness, goal setting, translating skills and experiences into job materials, and written and oral communication skills. The seminar also played an important role in cohort building among program participants. Additional cohort building activities included informal gatherings for students and program faculty and staff to discuss challenges, successes, and other topics of interest to students. S-STEM scholars were required to participate in professional development activities, such as career-related workshops, individual meetings with career consultants, science seminars presented by scientists from on- or off-campus, undergraduate research symposia, and student organization activities. The professional development requirement was designed to be flexible and allow students to tailor program experiences to their interests, needs, and/or schedules. S-STEM scholars also participated in frequent advising checkpoints with the lead faculty member for the project. Assessment outcomes from student interviews identified the importance of the cohort building activities (informal gatherings), a shared office space for students, one-on-one meetings (advising checkpoints) with the lead faculty member for the project, and financial support. Graduates of the program have gone on to careers in STEM disciplines and graduate school.
